column2: II
column3: two

column2: I confess I did not like it.
column3: I confess I did not like it.

column2: Although I had made up my mind to play, I felt averse to doing so on behalf of some one else.
column3: Although I had made up my mind to play, I felt averse to doing so on behalf of some one else.

column2: In fact, it almost upset my balance, and I entered the gaming rooms with an angry feeling at my heart.
column3: In fact, it almost upset my balance, and I entered the gaming rooms with an angry feeling at my heart.

column2: At first glance the scene irritated me.
column3: At first glance the scene irritated me.

column2: Never at any time have I been able to bear the flunkeyishness which one meets in the Press of the world at large, but more especially in that of Russia, where, almost every evening, journalists write on two subjects in particular namely, on the splendour and luxury of the casinos to be found in the Rhenish towns, and on the heaps of gold which are daily to be seen lying on their tables.
column3: Never at any time have I been able to bear the flunkeyishness which one meets in the Press of the world at large, but more especially in that of Russia, where, almost every evening, journalists write on two subjects in particular namely, on the splendour and luxury of the casinos to be found in the Rhenish towns, and on the heaps of gold which are daily to be seen lying on their tables.

column2: Those journalists are not paid for doing so: they write thus merely out of a spirit of disinterested complaisance.
column3: Those journalists are not paid for doing so: they write thus merely out of a spirit of disinterested complaisance.

column2: For there is nothing splendid about the establishments in question; and, not only are there no heaps of gold to be seen lying on their tables, but also there is very little money to be seen at all.
column3: For there is nothing splendid about the establishments in question; and, not only are there no heaps of gold to be seen lying on their tables, but also there is very little money to be seen at all.

column2: Of course, during the season, some madman or another may make his appearance--generally an Englishman, or an Asiatic, or a Turk--and (as had happened during the summer of which I write) win or lose a great deal; but, as regards the rest of the crowd, it plays only for petty gulden, and seldom does much wealth figure on the board.
column3: Of course, during the season, some madman or another may make his appearance-generally an Englishman, or an Asiatic, or a Turk-and (as had happened during the summer of which I write) win or lose a great deal; but, as regards the rest of the crowd, it plays only for petty gulden, and seldom does much wealth figure on the board.

column2: When, on the present occasion, I entered the gaming-rooms (for the first time in my life), it was several moments before I could even make up my mind to play.
column3: When, on the present occasion, I entered the gaming rooms (for the first time in my life), it was several moments before I could even make up my mind to play.

column2: For one thing, the crowd oppressed me.
column3: For one thing, the crowd oppressed me.

column2: Had I been playing for myself, I think I should have left at once, and never have embarked upon gambling at all, for I could feel my heart beginning to beat, and my heart was anything but cold-blooded.
column3: Had I been playing for myself, I think I should have left at once, and never have embarked upon gambling at all, for I could feel my heart beginning to beat, and my heart was anything but cold blooded.

column2: Also, I knew, I had long ago made up my mind, that never should I depart from Roulettenberg until some radical, some final, change had taken place in my fortunes. Thus, it must and would be.
column3: Also, I knew, I had long ago made up my mind, that never should I depart from Roulettenberg until some radical, some final, change had taken place in my fortunes. Thus, it must and would be.

column2: However ridiculous it may seem to you that I was expecting to win at roulette, I look upon the generally accepted opinion concerning the folly and the grossness of hoping to win at gambling as a thing even more absurd.
column3: However ridiculous it may seem to you that I was expecting to win at roulette, I look upon the generally accepted opinion concerning the folly and the grossness of hoping to win at gambling as a thing even more absurd.

column2: For why is gambling a whit worse than any other method of acquiring money?
column3: For why is gambling a whit worse than any other method of acquiring money?

column2: How, for instance, is it worse than trade?
column3: How, for instance, is it worse than trade?

column2: True, out of a hundred persons, only one can win; yet what business is that of yours or of mine?
column3: True, out of a hundred persons, only one can win; yet what business is that of yours or of mine?

column2: At all events, I confined myself at first simply to looking on, and decided to attempt nothing serious.
column3: At all events, I confined myself at first simply to looking on, and decided to attempt nothing serious.

column2: Indeed, I felt that, if I began to do anything at all, I should do it in an absent-minded, haphazard sort of way--of that I felt certain.
column3: Indeed, I felt that, if I began to do anything at all, I should do it in an absent minded, haphazard sort of way-of that I felt certain.

column2: Also, it behoved me to learn the game itself; since, despite a thousand descriptions of roulette which I had read with ceaseless avidity, I knew nothing of its rules, and had never even seen it played.
column3: Also, it behoved me to learn the game itself; since, despite a thousand descriptions of roulette which I had read with ceaseless avidity, I knew nothing of its rules, and had never even seen it played.

column2: In the first place, everything about it seemed to me so foul--so morally mean and foul.
column3: In the first place, everything about it seemed to me so foul-so morally mean and foul.

column2: Yet I am not speaking of the hungry, restless folk who, by scores nay, even by hundreds--could be seen crowded around the gaming-tables.
column3: Yet I am not speaking of the hungry, restless folk who, by scores nay, even by hundreds-could be seen crowded around the gaming tables.

column2: For in a desire to win quickly and to win much I can see nothing sordid; I have always applauded the opinion of a certain dead and gone, but cocksure, moralist who replied to the excuse that "one may always gamble moderately", by saying that to do so makes things worse, since, in that case, the profits too will always be moderate.
column3: For in a desire to win quickly and to win much I can see nothing sordid; I have always applauded the opinion of a certain dead and gone, but cocksure, moralist who replied to the excuse that "one may always gamble moderately", by saying that to do so makes things worse, since, in that case, the profits too will always be moderate.

column2: Insignificant profits and sumptuous profits do not stand on the same footing.
column3: Insignificant profits and sumptuous profits do not stand on the same footing.

column2: No, it is all a matter of proportion.
column3: No, it is all a matter of proportion.

column2: What may seem a small sum to a Rothschild may seem a large sum to me, and it is not the fault of stakes or of winnings that everywhere men can be found winning, can be found depriving their fellows of something, just as they do at roulette.
column3: What may seem a small sum to a Rothschild may seem a large sum to me, and it is not the fault of stakes or of winnings that everywhere men can be found winning, can be found depriving their fellows of something, just as they do at roulette.

column2: As to the question whether stakes and winnings are, in themselves, immoral is another question altogether, and I wish to express no opinion upon it.
column3: As to the question whether stakes and winnings are, in themselves, immoral is another question altogether, and I wish to express no opinion upon it.

column2: Yet the very fact that I was full of a strong desire to win caused this gambling for gain, in spite of its attendant squalor, to contain, if you will, something intimate, something sympathetic, to my eyes: for it is always pleasant to see men dispensing with ceremony, and acting naturally, and in an unbuttoned mood....
column3: Yet the very fact that I was full of a strong desire to win caused this gambling for gain, in spite of its attendant squalor, to contain, if you will, something intimate, something sympathetic, to my eyes: for it is always pleasant to see men dispensing with ceremony, and acting naturally, and in an unbuttoned mood....

column2: Yet, why should I so deceive myself?
column3: Yet, why should I so deceive myself?

column2: I could see that the whole thing was a vain and unreasoning pursuit; and what, at the first glance, seemed to me the ugliest feature in this mob of roulette players was their respect for their occupation--the seriousness, and even the humility, with which they stood around the gaming tables.
column3: I could see that the whole thing was a vain and unreasoning pursuit; and what, at the first glance, seemed to me the ugliest feature in this mob of roulette players was their respect for their occupation-the seriousness, and even the humility, with which they stood around the gaming tables.

column2: Moreover, I had always drawn sharp distinctions between a game which is de mauvais genre and a game which is permissible to a decent man.
column3: Moreover, I had always drawn sharp distinctions between a game which is de mauvais genre and a game which is permissible to a decent man.

column2: In fact, there are two sorts of gaming--namely, the game of the gentleman and the game of the plebs--the game for gain, and the game of the herd.
column3: In fact, there are two sorts of gaming-namely, the game of the gentleman and the game of the plebs-the game for gain, and the game of the herd.

column2: Herein, as said, I draw sharp distinctions.
column3: Herein, as said, I draw sharp distinctions.

column2: Yet how essentially base are the distinctions!
column3: Yet how essentially base are the distinctions!

column2: For instance, a gentleman may stake, say, five or ten louis d'or--seldom more, unless he is a very rich man, when he may stake, say, a thousand francs; but, he must do this simply for the love of the game itself--simply for sport, simply in order to observe the process of winning or of losing, and, above all things, as a man who remains quite uninterested in the possibility of his issuing a winner. If he wins, he will be at liberty, perhaps, to give vent to a laugh, or to pass a remark on the circumstance to a bystander, or to stake again, or to double his stake; but, even this he must do solely out of curiosity, and for the pleasure of watching the play of chances and of calculations, and not because of any vulgar desire to win.
column3: For instance, a gentleman may stake, say, five or ten louis d'or-seldom more, unless he is a very rich man, when he may stake, say, a thousand francs; but, he must do this simply for the love of the game itself-simply for sport, simply in order to observe the process of winning or of losing, and, above all things, as a man who remains quite uninterested in the possibility of his issuing a winner. If he wins, he will be at liberty, perhaps, to give vent to a laugh, or to pass a remark on the circumstance to a bystander, or to stake again, or to double his stake; but, even this he must do solely out of curiosity, and for the pleasure of watching the play of chances and of calculations, and not because of any vulgar desire to win.

column2: In a word, he must look upon the gaming-table, upon roulette, and upon trente et quarante, as mere relaxations which have been arranged solely for his amusement.
column3: In a word, he must look upon the gaming table, upon roulette, and upon trente et quarante, as mere relaxations which have been arranged solely for his amusement.

column2: Of the existence of the lures and gains upon which the bank is founded and maintained he must profess to have not an inkling.
column3: Of the existence of the lures and gains upon which the bank is founded and maintained he must profess to have not an inkling.

column2: Best of all, he ought to imagine his fellow-gamblers and the rest of the mob which stands trembling over a coin to be equally rich and gentlemanly with himself, and playing solely for recreation and pleasure.
column3: Best of all, he ought to imagine his fellow gamblers and the rest of the mob which stands trembling over a coin to be equally rich and gentlemanly with himself, and playing solely for recreation and pleasure.

column2: This complete ignorance of the realities, this innocent view of mankind, is what, in my opinion, constitutes the truly aristocratic.
column3: This complete ignorance of the realities, this innocent view of mankind, is what, in my opinion, constitutes the truly aristocratic.

column2: For instance, I have seen even fond mothers so far indulge their guileless, elegant daughters--misses of fifteen or sixteen--as to give them a few gold coins and teach them how to play; and though the young ladies may have won or have lost, they have invariably laughed, and departed as though they were well pleased.
column3: For instance, I have seen even fond mothers so far indulge their guileless, elegant daughters-misses of fifteen or sixteen-as to give them a few gold coins and teach them how to play; and though the young ladies may have won or have lost, they have invariably laughed, and departed as though they were well pleased.

column2: In the same way, I saw our General once approach the table in a stolid, important manner.
column3: In the same way, I saw our General once approach the table in a stolid, important manner.

column2: A lacquey darted to offer him a chair, but the General did not even notice him.
column3: A lacquey darted to offer him a chair, but the General did not even notice him.

column2: Slowly he took out his money bags, and slowly extracted 300 francs in gold, which he staked on the black, and won.
column3: Slowly he took out his money bags, and slowly extracted three hundred francs in gold, which he staked on the black, and won.

column2: Yet he did not take up his winnings--he left them there on the table.
column3: Yet he did not take up his winnings-he left them there on the table.

column2: Again the black turned up, and again he did not gather in what he had won; and when, in the third round, the RED turned up he lost, at a stroke, 1200 francs.
column3: Again the black turned up, and again he did not gather in what he had won; and when, in the third round, the RED turned up he lost, at a stroke, twelve hundred francs.

column2: Yet even then he rose with a smile, and thus preserved his reputation; yet I knew that his money bags must be chafing his heart, as well as that, had the stake been twice or thrice as much again, he would still have restrained himself from venting his disappointment.
column3: Yet even then he rose with a smile, and thus preserved his reputation; yet I knew that his money bags must be chafing his heart, as well as that, had the stake been twice or thrice as much again, he would still have restrained himself from venting his disappointment.

column2: On the other hand, I saw a Frenchman first win, and then lose, 30,000 francs cheerfully, and without a murmur.
column3: On the other hand, I saw a Frenchman first win, and then lose, thirty thousand francs cheerfully, and without a murmur.

column2: Yes; even if a gentleman should lose his whole substance, he must never give way to annoyance. Money must be so subservient to gentility as never to be worth a thought.
column3: Yes; even if a gentleman should lose his whole substance, he must never give way to annoyance. Money must be so subservient to gentility as never to be worth a thought.

column2: Of course, the SUPREMELY aristocratic thing is to be entirely oblivious of the mire of rabble, with its setting; but sometimes a reverse course may be aristocratic to remark, to scan, and even to gape at, the mob (for preference, through a lorgnette), even as though one were taking the crowd and its squalor for a sort of raree show which had been organised specially for a gentleman's diversion.
column3: Of course, the SUPREMELY aristocratic thing is to be entirely oblivious of the mire of rabble, with its setting; but sometimes a reverse course may be aristocratic to remark, to scan, and even to gape at, the mob (for preference, through a lorgnette), even as though one were taking the crowd and its squalor for a sort of raree show which had been organised specially for a gentleman's diversion.

column2: Though one may be squeezed by the crowd, one must look as though one were fully assured of being the observer--of having neither part nor lot with the observed.
column3: Though one may be squeezed by the crowd, one must look as though one were fully assured of being the observer-of having neither part nor lot with the observed.

column2: At the same time, to stare fixedly about one is unbecoming; for that, again, is ungentlemanly, seeing that no spectacle is worth an open stare--are no spectacles in the world which merit from a gentleman too pronounced an inspection.
column3: At the same time, to stare fixedly about one is unbecoming; for that, again, is ungentlemanly, seeing that no spectacle is worth an open stare-are no spectacles in the world which merit from a gentleman too pronounced an inspection.

column2: However, to me personally the scene DID seem to be worth undisguised contemplation--more especially in view of the fact that I had come there not only to look at, but also to number myself sincerely and wholeheartedly with, the mob.
column3: However, to me personally the scene DID seem to be worth undisguised contemplation-more especially in view of the fact that I had come there not only to look at, but also to number myself sincerely and wholeheartedly with, the mob.

column2: As for my secret moral views, I had no room for them amongst my actual, practical opinions.
column3: As for my secret moral views, I had no room for them amongst my actual, practical opinions.

column2: Let that stand as written: I am writing only to relieve my conscience.
column3: Let that stand as written: I am writing only to relieve my conscience.

column2: Yet let me say also this: that from the first I have been consistent in having an intense aversion to any trial of my acts and thoughts by a moral standard.
column3: Yet let me say also this: that from the first I have been consistent in having an intense aversion to any trial of my acts and thoughts by a moral standard.

column2: Another standard altogether has directed my life....
column3: Another standard altogether has directed my life....

column2: As a matter of fact, the mob was playing in exceedingly foul fashion. Indeed, I have an idea that sheer robbery was going on around that gaming-table.
column3: As a matter of fact, the mob was playing in exceedingly foul fashion. Indeed, I have an idea that sheer robbery was going on around that gaming table.

column2: The croupiers who sat at the two ends of it had not only to watch the stakes, but also to calculate the game--an immense amount of work for two men!
column3: The croupiers who sat at the two ends of it had not only to watch the stakes, but also to calculate the game-an immense amount of work for two men!

column2: As for the crowd itself--well, it consisted mostly of Frenchmen.
column3: As for the crowd itself-well, it consisted mostly of Frenchmen.

column2: Yet I was not then taking notes merely in order to be able to give you a description of roulette, but in order to get my bearings as to my behaviour when I myself should begin to play.
column3: Yet I was not then taking notes merely in order to be able to give you a description of roulette, but in order to get my bearings as to my behaviour when I myself should begin to play.

column2: For example, I noticed that nothing was more common than for another's hand to stretch out and grab one's winnings whenever one had won.
column3: For example, I noticed that nothing was more common than for another's hand to stretch out and grab one's winnings whenever one had won.

column2: Then there would arise a dispute, and frequently an uproar; and it would be a case of "I beg of you to prove, and to produce witnesses to the fact, that the stake is yours."
column3: Then there would arise a dispute, and frequently an uproar; and it would be a case of "I beg of you to prove, and to produce witnesses to the fact, that the stake is yours."

column2: At first the proceedings were pure Greek to me.
column3: At first the proceedings were pure Greek to me.

column2: I could only divine and distinguish that stakes were hazarded on numbers, on "odd" or "even," and on colours.
column3: I could only divine and distinguish that stakes were hazarded on numbers, on "odd" or "even," and on colours.

column2: Polina's money I decided to risk, that evening, only to the amount of 100 gulden.
column3: Polina's money I decided to risk, that evening, only to the amount of one hundred gulden.

column2: The thought that I was not going to play for myself quite unnerved me.
column3: The thought that I was not going to play for myself quite unnerved me.

column2: It was an unpleasant sensation, and I tried hard to banish it.
column3: It was an unpleasant sensation, and I tried hard to banish it.

column2: I had a feeling that, once I had begun to play for Polina, I should wreck my own fortunes.
column3: I had a feeling that, once I had begun to play for Polina, I should wreck my own fortunes.

column2: Also, I wonder if any one has EVER approached a gaming-table without falling an immediate prey to superstition?
column3: Also, I wonder if any one has EVER approached a gaming table without falling an immediate prey to superstition?

column2: I began by pulling out fifty gulden, and staking them on "even." The wheel spun and stopped at 13.
column3: I began by pulling out fifty gulden, and staking them on "even." The wheel spun and stopped at thirteen.

column2: I had lost!
column3: I had lost!

column2: With a feeling like a sick qualm, as though I would like to make my way out of the crowd and go home, I staked another fifty gulden--this time on the red. The red turned up.
column3: With a feeling like a sick qualm, as though I would like to make my way out of the crowd and go home, I staked another fifty gulden-this time on the red. The red turned up.

column2: Next time I staked the 100 gulden just where they lay--and again the red turned up.
column3: Next time I staked the one hundred gulden just where they lay-and again the red turned up.

column2: Again I staked the whole sum, and again the red turned up.
column3: Again I staked the whole sum, and again the red turned up.

column2: Clutching my 400 gulden, I placed 200 of them on twelve figures, to see what would come of it.
column3: Clutching my four hundred gulden, I placed two hundred of them on twelve figures, to see what would come of it.

column2: The result was that the croupier paid me out three times my total stake!
column3: The result was that the croupier paid me out three times my total stake!

column2: Thus from 100 gulden my store had grown to 800!
column3: Thus from one hundred gulden my store had grown to eight hundred!

column2: Upon that such a curious, such an inexplicable, unwonted feeling overcame me that I decided to depart. Always the thought kept recurring to me that if I had been playing for myself alone I should never have had such luck.
column3: Upon that such a curious, such an inexplicable, unwonted feeling overcame me that I decided to depart. Always the thought kept recurring to me that if I had been playing for myself alone I should never have had such luck.

column2: Once more I staked the whole 800 gulden on the "even." The wheel stopped at 4.
column3: Once more I staked the whole eight hundred gulden on the "even." The wheel stopped at four.

column2: I was paid out another 800 gulden, and, snatching up my pile of 1600, departed in search of Polina Alexandrovna.
column3: I was paid out another eight hundred gulden, and, snatching up my pile of sixteen hundred, departed in search of Polina Alexandrovna.

column2: I found the whole party walking in the park, and was able to get an interview with her only after supper.
column3: I found the whole party walking in the park, and was able to get an interview with her only after supper.

column2: This time the Frenchman was absent from the meal, and the General seemed to be in a more expansive vein.
column3: This time the Frenchman was absent from the meal, and the General seemed to be in a more expansive vein.

column2: Among other things, he thought it necessary to remind me that he would be sorry to see me playing at the gaming-tables.
column3: Among other things, he thought it necessary to remind me that he would be sorry to see me playing at the gaming tables.

column2: In his opinion, such conduct would greatly compromise him--especially if I were to lose much.
column3: In his opinion, such conduct would greatly compromise him-especially if I were to lose much.

column2: And even if you were to WIN much I should be compromised, he added in a meaning sort of way.
column3: And even if you were to WIN much I should be compromised, he added in a meaning sort of way.

column2: Of course I have no RIGHT to order your actions, but you yourself will agree that... As usual, he did not finish his sentence.
column3: Of course I have no RIGHT to order your actions, but you yourself will agree that... As usual, he did not finish his sentence.

column2: I answered drily that I had very little money in my possession, and that, consequently, I was hardly in a position to indulge in any conspicuous play, even if I did gamble.
column3: I answered drily that I had very little money in my possession, and that, consequently, I was hardly in a position to indulge in any conspicuous play, even if I did gamble.

column2: At last, when ascending to my own room, I succeeded in handing Polina her winnings, and told her that, next time, I should not play for her.
column3: At last, when ascending to my own room, I succeeded in handing Polina her winnings, and told her that, next time, I should not play for her.

column2: Why not? she asked excitedly.
column3: Why not? she asked excitedly.

column2: Because I wish to play FOR MYSELF, I replied with a feigned glance of astonishment.
column3: Because I wish to play FOR MYSELF, I replied with a feigned glance of astonishment.

column2: That is my sole reason.
column3: That is my sole reason.

column2: Then are you so certain that your roulette-playing will get us out of our difficulties? she inquired with a quizzical smile.
column3: Then are you so certain that your roulette playing will get us out of our difficulties? she inquired with a quizzical smile.

column2: I said very seriously, "Yes," and then added: "Possibly my certainty about winning may seem to you ridiculous; yet, pray leave me in peace."
column3: I said very seriously, "Yes," and then added: "Possibly my certainty about winning may seem to you ridiculous; yet, pray leave me in peace."

column2: Nonetheless she insisted that I ought to go halves with her in the day's winnings, and offered me 800 gulden on condition that henceforth, I gambled only on those terms; but I refused to do so, once and for all--stating, as my reason, that I found myself unable to play on behalf of any one else, "I am not unwilling so to do," I added, "but in all probability I should lose."
column3: Nonetheless she insisted that I ought to go halves with her in the day's winnings, and offered me eight hundred gulden on condition that henceforth, I gambled only on those terms; but I refused to do so, once and for all-stating, as my reason, that I found myself unable to play on behalf of any one else, "I am not unwilling so to do," I added, "but in all probability I should lose."

column2: Well, absurd though it be, I place great hopes on your playing of roulette, she remarked musingly; "wherefore, you ought to play as my partner and on equal shares; wherefore, of course, you will do as I wish."
column3: Well, absurd though it be, I place great hopes on your playing of roulette, she remarked musingly; "wherefore, you ought to play as my partner and on equal shares; wherefore, of course, you will do as I wish."

column2: Then she left me without listening to any further protests on my part.
column3: Then she left me without listening to any further protests on my part.
